title: The deconvolution of thermoluminescence glow-curves using general expressions derived from the one trap-one recombination (OTOR) level model
abstract: The new developed thermoluminescence (TL) glow-peak expressions derived from the one trap-one recombination (OTOR) level model were used to analyze the TL glow-curves recorded with linear and exponential heating function profiles under various experimental conditions. The results showed that these expressions can, accurately, analyze the TL glow-curves even with the overlapped glow-peaks. Low values of R = A n / A m were reported for glow-peaks in different TL materials. A glow-peak with the possibility of A n > A m was also pointed out. • The accuracy of the TL expressions derived from the OTOR model was verified. • EHF and LHF glow-curves were deconvoluted using TL expressions based on OTOR model. • Low values of R = A n / A m were reported for some glow-peaks. • A glow-peak with the possibility of A n > A m was pointed out.

motivations: Thermoluminescence (TL) glow-curves often exhibit overlapped glow-peaks, making accurate analysis challenging.
Existing methods may struggle to accurately deconvolute TL glow-curves, particularly under varying experimental conditions.
objectives: Evaluate the effectiveness of newly developed TL glow-peak expressions derived from the one trap-one recombination (OTOR) level model in analyzing TL glow-curves.
Demonstrate the accuracy of these expressions in deconvoluting TL glow-curves with overlapped glow-peaks under different experimental conditions.
methods: Utilize TL glow-peak expressions derived from the OTOR model to analyze TL glow-curves recorded with linear and exponential heating function profiles.
Apply these expressions to deconvolute TL glow-curves with overlapped glow-peaks under various experimental conditions.
results: The TL expressions derived from the OTOR model accurately analyzed TL glow-curves, even with overlapped glow-peaks.
Low values of R = A n / A m were reported for glow-peaks in different TL materials, and a glow-peak with the possibility of A n > A m was identified.

results: The TL expressions derived from the OTOR model accurately analyzed the TL glow-curves, even those with overlapped glow-peaks.

A glow-peak with the possibility of A n > A m was identified.

motivations: Existing methods for analyzing thermoluminescence glow-curves face challenges in accurately deconvoluting overlapped glow-peaks.
There is a need for improved theoretical models to analyze TL glow-curves under various experimental conditions and heating profiles.
objectives: Develop and validate new thermoluminescence glow-peak expressions derived from the one trap-one recombination (OTOR) level model.
Analyze TL glow-curves recorded with linear and exponential heating function profiles to demonstrate the accuracy of the new expressions.
methods: Derive general expressions for TL glow-peaks based on the one trap-one recombination (OTOR) level model.
Apply these expressions to deconvolute TL glow-curves recorded under various experimental conditions with different heating profiles.
results: The new expressions accurately analyzed TL glow-curves including those with overlapped glow-peaks.
Low values of R = An/Am were identified for glow-peaks in different TL materials, with some peaks showing the possibility of An > Am.
